channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: What Is Dark Web Monitoring? | UpGuard
item.description: Understand what dark web monitoring is, and why it’s essential for third-party risk management. Learn how UpGuard helps detect exposed data in real-time.

item.title: Kimsuky Debuts HTTPTroy Backdoor Against South Korea Users
item.description: The well-known North Korean threat group continues to improve the obfuscation and anti-analysis features of its attack toolchain.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Pro-Russian Hackers Use Linux VMs to Hide in Windows
item.description: A threat actor known as &quot;Curly COMrades&quot; is using Linux VMs to remain undetected in Windows environments while conducting Russia-aligned activities.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Europe Sees Increase in Ransomware, Extortion Attacks
item.description: European organizations face an escalating cyber threat landscape as attackers leverage geopolitical tensions and AI-enhanced social engineering for attacks.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: A Cybercrime Merger Like No Other — Scattered Spider, LAPSUS$, and ShinyHunters Join Forces
item.description: The nascent collective that combines three prominent cybercrime groups, Scattered Spider, LAPSUS$, and ShinyHunters, has created no less than 16 Telegram channels since August 8, 2025. "Since its debut, the group's Telegram channels have been removed and recreated at least 16 times under varying iterations of the original name – a recurring cycle reflecting platform moderation and the operators'
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Europol and Eurojust Dismantle €600 Million Crypto Fraud Network in Global Sweep
item.description: Nine people have been arrested in connection with a coordinated law enforcement operation that targeted a cryptocurrency money laundering network that defrauded victims of €600 million (~$688 million). According to a statement released by Eurojust today, the action took place between October 27 and 29 across Cyprus, Spain, and Germany, with the suspects arrested on charges of involvement in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: French Police Seize €1.6m Amid Crypto Scam Network Crackdown
item.description: Nine alleged crypto scammers arrested in Cyprus, Germany and Spain

item.title: OpenAI Assistants API Exploited in 'SesameOp' Backdoor
item.description: Instead of relying on more traditional methods, the backdoor exploits OpenAI’s Assistants API for command-and-control communications

item.title: SesameOp Backdoor Uses OpenAI API for Covert C2
item.description: Malware used in a months-long attack demonstrates how bad actors are misusing generative AI services in unique and stealthy ways.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Critical React Native CLI Flaw Exposed Millions of Developers to Remote Attacks
item.description: Details have emerged about a now-patched critical security flaw in the popular "@react-native-community/cli" npm package that could be potentially exploited to run malicious operating system (OS) commands under certain conditions. "The vulnerability allows remote unauthenticated attackers to easily trigger arbitrary OS command execution on the machine running react-native-community/cli's
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Scattered Spider, ShinyHunters and LAPSUS$ Form Unified Collective
item.description: Scattered Spider, ShinyHunters and LAPSUS$ have formed an enhanced coordinated threat network for extortion efforts

item.title: Microsoft Teams Bugs Let Attackers Impersonate Colleagues and Edit Messages Unnoticed
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of four security flaws in Microsoft Teams that could have exposed users to serious impersonation and social engineering attacks. The vulnerabilities "allowed attackers to manipulate conversations, impersonate colleagues, and exploit notifications," Check Point said in a report shared with The Hacker News. Following responsible disclosure in March
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: DragonForce Cartel Emerges as Conti-Derived Ransomware Threat
item.description: DragonForce, a ransomware group using Conti’s code, has adopted a cartel model to expand and recruit

item.title: Identity Is Now the Top Source of Cloud Risk
item.description: ReliaQuest data reveals identity issues were responsible for 44% of cloud security alerts in Q3

item.title: Cybercriminals Targeting Payroll Sites
item.description: <p>Microsoft is <a href="https://thehackernews.com/2025/10/microsoft-warns-of-payroll-pirates.html?_m=3n%2e009a%2e3796%2ebx0ao08q8s%2e2u1l">warning</a> of a scam involving online payroll systems. Criminals use social engineering to steal people&#8217;s credentials, and then divert direct deposits into accounts that they control. Sometimes they do other things to make it harder for the victim to realize what is happening.</p> <p>I feel like this kind of thing is happening everywhere, with everything. As we move more of our personal and professional lives online, we enable criminals to subvert the very systems we rely on.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Ransomware Defense Using the Wazuh Open Source Platform
item.description: Ransomware is malicious software designed to block access to a computer system or encrypt data until a ransom is paid. This cyberattack is one of the most prevalent and damaging threats in the digital landscape, affecting individuals, businesses, and critical infrastructure worldwide. A ransomware attack typically begins when the malware infiltrates a system through various vectors such as
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Operation SkyCloak Deploys Tor-Enabled OpenSSH Backdoor Targeting Defense Sectors
item.description: Threat actors are leveraging weaponized attachments distributed via phishing emails to deliver malware likely targeting the defense sector in Russia and Belarus. According to multiple reports from Cyble and Seqrite Labs, the campaign is designed to deploy a persistent backdoor on compromised hosts that uses OpenSSH in conjunction with a customized Tor hidden service that employs obfs4 for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: DeFi Protocol Balancer Loses Over $120m in Cyber Heist
item.description: Digital thieves have got away with over $120m stolen from popular decentralized finance protocol Balancer

item.title: Google’s AI ‘Big Sleep’ Finds 5 New Vulnerabilities in Apple’s Safari WebKit
item.description:
Google's artificial intelligence (AI)-powered cybersecurity agent called Big Sleep has been credited by Apple for discovering as many as five different security flaws in the WebKit component used in its Safari web browser that, if successfully exploited, could result in a browser crash or memory corruption. The list of vulnerabilities is as follows -
CVE-2025-43429 - A buffer overflow
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: IT Leader’s Guide to Cyberwarfare
item.description: <p>For IT leaders, understanding this evolving threat landscape is no longer optional, but a core component of organizational resilience and national security. Constantly Updated — The guide contains the latest and most accurate details. Boost Your Cyberwarfare Knowledge — This 15-page PDF covers definitions, deterrence, preparation, and more. Expert Guidance — Written by TechRepublic staff ...</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/resource-library/guide/cyberwarfare/">IT Leader’s Guide to Cyberwarfare</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: U.S. Prosecutors Indict Cybersecurity Insiders Accused of BlackCat Ransomware Attacks
item.description: Federal prosecutors in the U.S. have accused a trio of allegedly hacking the networks of five U.S. companies with BlackCat (aka ALPHV) ransomware between May and November 2023 and extorting them. Ryan Clifford Goldberg, Kevin Tyler Martin, and an unnamed co–conspirator (aka "Co-Conspirator 1") based in Florida, all U.S. nationals, are said to have used the ransomware strain against a medical
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Proofpoint Report: Gen AI Adoption, Data Growth, and Insider Risks Are Converging to Create Unprecedented Data Security Challenges
Microsoft Detects "SesameOp" Backdoor Using OpenAI's API as a Stealth Command Channel
item.description: Microsoft has disclosed details of a novel backdoor dubbed SesameOp that uses OpenAI Assistants Application Programming Interface (API) for command-and-control (C2) communications. "Instead of relying on more traditional methods, the threat actor behind this backdoor abuses OpenAI as a C2 channel as a way to stealthily communicate and orchestrate malicious activities within the compromised
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Android Malware Mutes Alerts, Drains Crypto Wallets
item.description: Android/BankBot-YNRK is currently targeting users in Indonesia by masquerading as legitimate applications.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: On the Road Again: Hackers Hijack Physical Cargo Freight
item.description: In a new cyber threat campaign, attackers are using remote monitoring and management tools to actually steal physical cargo out of the trucking and freight supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Malicious VSX Extension "SleepyDuck" Uses Ethereum to Keep Its Command Server Alive
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have flagged a new malicious extension in the Open VSX registry that harbors a remote access trojan called SleepyDuck. According to Secure Annex's John Tuckner, the extension in question, juan-bianco.solidity-vlang (version 0.0.7), was first published on October 31, 2025, as a completely benign library that was subsequently updated to version 0.0.8 on November 1 to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA and NSA Outline Best Practices to Secure Exchange Servers
item.description: CISA and NSA have released a blueprint to enhance Microsoft Exchange Server security against cyber-attacks

item.title: New GDI Flaws Could Enable Remote Code Execution in Windows
item.description: Flaws in Windows Graphics Device Interface (GDI) have been identified that allow remote code execution and information disclosure

item.title: The AI Exchange: Innovators in Payment Security Featuring Block, Inc.
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Hackers Help Organized Crime Groups in Cargo Freight Heists, Researchers Find
item.description: Proofpoint researchers have observed recent hacking campaigns supporting cargo theft

item.title: Let's Get Physical: A New Convergence for Electrical Grid Security
item.description: The power grid is being attacked online and IRL. Increasingly, regulators and industry experts agree: Security teams need to focus on both cyber and physical threats, together.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Android’s AI Blocks 58% More Scams Than iPhone, Study Shows
item.description: <p>Google’s AI-driven security systems block over 10 billion malicious communications every month.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-android-ai-blocks-scams/">Android&#8217;s AI Blocks 58% More Scams Than iPhone, Study Shows</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Cybercriminals Exploit Remote Monitoring Tools to Infiltrate Logistics and Freight Networks
item.description: Bad actors are increasingly training their sights on trucking and logistics companies with an aim to infect them with remote monitoring and management (RMM) software for financial gain and ultimately steal cargo freight. The threat cluster, believed to be active since at least June 2025 according to Proofpoint, is said to be collaborating with organized crime groups to break into entities in the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Lazarus Hits Web3, Intel/AMD TEEs Cracked, Dark Web Leak Tool & More
item.description: Cyberattacks are getting smarter and harder to stop. This week, hackers used sneaky tools, tricked trusted systems, and quickly took advantage of new security problems—some just hours after being found. No system was fully safe. From spying and fake job scams to strong ransomware and tricky phishing, the attacks came from all sides. Even encrypted backups and secure areas were put to the test.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI Summarization Optimization
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: AI Developed Code: 5 Critical Security Checkpoints for Human Oversight
item.description: To write secure code with LLMs developers must have the skills to use AI as a collaborative assistant rather than an autonomous tool, Madou argues.
item.dc:creator: Matias Madou

item.title: Government Agencies Issue Emergency Guidance for Microsoft Exchange Server
item.description: <p>The NSA, CISA, Australia's Cyber Security Centre, and Canada's Cyber Centre jointly released comprehensive security practices for Exchange hardening. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-guidance-microsoft-exchange-server/">Government Agencies Issue Emergency Guidance for Microsoft Exchange Server</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: The Evolution of SOC Operations: How Continuous Exposure Management Transforms Security Operations
item.description: Security Operations Centers (SOC) today are overwhelmed. Analysts handle thousands of alerts every day, spending much time chasing false positives and adjusting detection rules reactively. SOCs often lack the environmental context and relevant threat intelligence needed to quickly verify which alerts are truly malicious. As a result, analysts spend excessive time manually triaging alerts, the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Uncover BankBot-YNRK and DeliveryRAT Android Trojans Stealing Financial Data
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have shed light on two different Android trojans called BankBot-YNRK and DeliveryRAT that are capable of harvesting sensitive data from compromised devices. According to CYFIRMA, which analyzed three different samples of BankBot-YNRK, the malware incorporates features to sidestep analysis efforts by first checking its running within a virtualized or emulated environment
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 'TruffleNet' Attack Wields Stolen Credentials Against AWS
item.description: Reconnaissance and BEC are among the malicious activities attackers commit after compromising cloud accounts, using a framework based on the TruffleHog tool.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: New HttpTroy Backdoor Poses as VPN Invoice in Targeted Cyberattack on South Korea
item.description: The North Korea-linked threat actor known as Kimsuky has distributed a previously undocumented backdoor codenamed HttpTroy as part of a likely spear-phishing attack targeting a single victim in South Korea. Gen Digital, which disclosed details of the activity, did not reveal any details on when the incident occurred, but noted that the phishing email contained a ZIP file ("250908_A_HK이노션
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Conti Suspect in Court After Extradition From Ireland
item.description: Ukrainian national Oleksii Oleksiyovych Lytvynenko has appeared in a US court in connection with Conti ransomware charges

item.title: Ground zero: 5 things to do after discovering a cyberattack
item.description: When every minute counts, preparation and precision can mean the difference between disruption and disaster

item.title: Leak Site Ransomware Victims Spike 13% in a Year
item.description: CrowdStrike data reveals a 13% annual increase in the number of European ransomware victims in 2025

item.title: Proofpoint Named Official Cybersecurity Partner of TGL Presented by SoFi
Lookalike Domain Attacks Explained | UpGuard
item.description: Learn about lookalike domain attacks, why they’re on the rise, and how to prevent them using automated monitoring and layered cybersecurity defenses.

item.title: Alleged Jabber Zeus Coder ‘MrICQ’ in U.S. Custody
item.description:
A Ukrainian man indicted in 2012 for conspiring with a prolific hacking group to steal tens of millions of dollars from U.S. businesses was arrested in Italy and is now in custody in the United States, KrebsOnSecurity has learned.
Sources close to the investigation say Yuriy Igorevich Rybtsov, a 41-year-old from the Russia-controlled city of Donetsk, Ukraine, was previously referenced in U.S. federal charging documents only by his online handle "MrICQ." According to a 13-year-old indictment filed by prosecutors in Nebraska, MrICQ was a developer for a cybercrime group known as "Jabber Zeus."
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: ASD Warns of Ongoing BADCANDY Attacks Exploiting Cisco IOS XE Vulnerability
item.description: The Australian Signals Directorate (ASD) has issued a bulletin about ongoing cyber attacks targeting unpatched Cisco IOS XE devices in the country with a previously undocumented implant known as BADCANDY. The activity, per the intelligence agency, involves the exploitation of CVE-2023-20198 (CVSS score: 10.0), a critical vulnerability that allows a remote, unauthenticated attacker to create an
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: UNC6384 Targets European Diplomatic Entities With Windows Exploit
item.description: The spear-phishing campaign uses fake European Commission and NATO-themed lures to trick diplomatic personnel into clicking malicious links.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Ribbon Communications Breach Marks Latest Telecom Attack
item.description: The US telecom company disclosed that suspected nation-state actors first gained access to its network in December of last year, though it's unclear if attackers obtained sensitive data.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: OpenAI Unveils Aardvark: GPT-5 Agent That Finds and Fixes Code Flaws Automatically
item.description: OpenAI has announced the launch of an "agentic security researcher" that's powered by its GPT-5 large language model (LLM) and is programmed to emulate a human expert capable of scanning, understanding, and patching code. Called Aardvark, the artificial intelligence (AI) company said the autonomous agent is designed to help developers and security teams flag and fix security vulnerabilities at
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Nation-State Hackers Deploy New Airstalk Malware in Suspected Supply Chain Attack
item.description: A suspected nation-state threat actor has been linked to the distribution of a new malware called Airstalk as part of a likely supply chain attack. Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 said it's tracking the cluster under the moniker CL-STA-1009, where "CL" stands for cluster and "STA" refers to state-backed motivation. "Airstalk misuses the AirWatch API for mobile device management (MDM), which is now
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Canada Warns of Cyberattacks Targeting Industrial Control Systems
item.description: <p>Hackers breached Canadian water, energy, and farm systems, prompting national warnings to secure industrial control networks.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-canada-critical-infrastructure-attacks/">Canada Warns of Cyberattacks Targeting Industrial Control Systems</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: Government Approach to Disrupt Cyber Scams is 'Fragmented'
item.description: Users contend with cybersecurity scams throughout their day; a new Cyber Civic Engagement program wants to provide them with the skills to fight back.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Conduent Data Breach Impacts Over 10.5 Million Individuals
item.description: Over 10.5 million individuals were impacted by a widespread 2024 data breach at Conduent Business Services, with customer notifications issued in October 2025

item.title: China-Linked Hackers Exploit Windows Shortcut Flaw to Target European Diplomats
item.description: A China-affiliated threat actor known as UNC6384 has been linked to a fresh set of attacks exploiting an unpatched Windows shortcut vulnerability to target European diplomatic and government entities between September and October 2025. The activity targeted diplomatic organizations in Hungary, Belgium, Italy, and the Netherlands, as well as government agencies in Serbia, Arctic Wolf said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: China-Linked Tick Group Exploits Lanscope Zero-Day to Hijack Corporate Systems
item.description: The exploitation of a recently disclosed critical security flaw in Motex Lanscope Endpoint Manager has been attributed to a cyber espionage group known as Tick. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-61932 (CVSS score: 9.3), allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands with SYSTEM privileges on on-premise versions of the program. JPCERT/CC, in an alert issued this month, said that it
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The MSP Cybersecurity Readiness Guide: Turning Security into Growth
item.description: MSPs are facing rising client expectations for strong cybersecurity and compliance outcomes, while threats grow more complex and regulatory demands evolve. Meanwhile, clients are increasingly seeking comprehensive protection without taking on the burden of managing security themselves. This shift represents a major growth opportunity. By delivering advanced cybersecurity and compliance
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Dark Reading Confidential Episode 11: Enterprise cyber teams are in prime position to push back against our current &quot;Golden Age of Surveillance,&quot; according to our guests Ronald Deibert from Citizen Lab and David Greene from the EFF.

item.title: CISA and NSA Issue Urgent Guidance to Secure WSUS and Microsoft Exchange Servers
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and National Security Agency (NSA), along with international partners from Australia and Canada, have released guidance to harden on-premise Microsoft Exchange Server instances from potential exploitation. "By restricting administrative access, implementing multi-factor authentication, enforcing strict transport security
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Revokes Leaked Open VSX Tokens Following Wiz Discovery
item.description: Eclipse Foundation, which maintains the open-source Open VSX project, said it has taken steps to revoke a small number of tokens that were leaked within Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions published in the marketplace. The action comes following a report from cloud security company Wiz earlier this month, which found several extensions from both Microsoft's VS Code Marketplace and Open VSX
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Flags VMware Zero-Day Exploited by China-Linked Hackers in Active Attacks
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added a high-severity security flaw impacting Broadcom VMware Tools and VMware Aria Operations to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, following reports of active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-41244 (CVSS score: 7.8), which could be exploited by an attacker to attain
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: A New Security Layer for macOS Takes Aim at Admin Errors Before Hackers Do
item.description: A design firm is editing a new campaign video on a MacBook Pro. The creative director opens a collaboration app that quietly requests microphone and camera permissions. MacOS is supposed to flag that, but in this case, the checks are loose. The app gets access anyway. On another Mac in the same office, file sharing is enabled through an old protocol called SMB version one. It’s fast and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Salesforce Extortion Accelerates With New Leak Site | UpGuard
item.description: The hacker collective Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters has launched a new leak site threatening to release data stolen from Salesforce instances.

item.title: Zombie Projects Rise Again to Undermine Security
item.description: Companies left them for dead, but the remnants of old infrastructure and failed projects continue to haunt businesses' security teams.

item.title: An 18-Year-Old Codebase Left Smart Buildings Wide Open
item.description: Researcher Gjoko Krstic's &quot;Project Brainfog&quot; exposed hundreds of zero-day vulnerabilities in building-automation systems still running hospitals, schools, and offices worldwide.

item.title: US Stands Out in Refusal to Sign UN Cybercrime Treaty
item.description: The agreement aims to help law enforcement prosecute cross-border cybercrime, but the final treaty could allow unchecked surveillance and human-rights abuses, critics say; and, it includes no protection for pen testers.

item.title: Critical Claroty Authentication Bypass Flaw Opened OT to Attack
item.description: CVE-2025-54603 gave attackers an opening to disrupt critical operational technology (OT) environments and critical infrastructure, plus steal data from them.

item.title: LotL Attack Hides Malware in Windows Native AI Stack
item.description: Security programs trust AI data files, but they shouldn't: they can conceal malware more stealthily than most file types.

item.title: Google's Built-In AI Defenses on Android Now Block 10 Billion Scam Messages a Month
item.description: Google on Thursday revealed that the scam defenses built into Android safeguard users around the world from more than 10 billion suspected malicious calls and messages every month. The tech giant also said it has blocked over 100 million suspicious numbers from using Rich Communication Services (RCS), an evolution of the SMS protocol, thereby preventing scams before they could even be sent. In
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Russian Ransomware Gangs Weaponize Open-Source AdaptixC2 for Advanced Attacks
item.description: The open-source command-and-control (C2) framework known as AdaptixC2 is being used by a growing number of threat actors, some of whom are related to Russian ransomware gangs. AdaptixC2 is an emerging extensible post-exploitation and adversarial emulation framework designed for penetration testing. While the server component is written in Golang, the GUI Client is written in C++ QT for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New "Brash" Exploit Crashes Chromium Browsers Instantly with a Single Malicious URL
item.description: A severe vulnerability disclosed in Chromium's Blink rendering engine can be exploited to crash many Chromium-based browsers within a few seconds. Security researcher Jose Pino, who disclosed details of the flaw, has codenamed it Brash. "It allows any Chromium browser to collapse in 15-60 seconds by exploiting an architectural flaw in how certain DOM operations are managed," Pino said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cloud Outages Highlight the Need for Resilient, Secure Infrastructure Recovery
item.description: Two massive technical outages over the past year underscore the need for cybersecurity teams to consider how to recover safely from disruptions without creating new security risks.

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: DNS Poisoning Flaw, Supply-Chain Heist, Rust Malware Trick and New RATs Rising
item.description: The comfort zone in cybersecurity is gone. Attackers are scaling down, focusing tighter, and squeezing more value from fewer, high-impact targets. At the same time, defenders face growing blind spots &mdash; from spoofed messages to large-scale social engineering. This week&rsquo;s findings show how that shrinking margin of safety is redrawing the threat landscape. Here&rsquo;s what&rsquo;s
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: PhantomRaven Malware Found in 126 npm Packages Stealing GitHub Tokens From Devs
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have uncovered yet another active software supply chain attack campaign targeting the npm registry with over 100 malicious packages that can steal authentication tokens, CI/CD secrets, and GitHub credentials from developers' machines. The campaign has been codenamed PhantomRaven by Koi Security. The activity is assessed to have begun in August 2025, when the first
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fraud prevention: How to help older family members avoid scams
item.description: Families that combine open communication with effective behavioral and technical safeguards can cut the risk dramatically

item.title: Data Leak Outs Hacker Students of Iran's MOIS Training Academy
item.description: Ravin Academy, a school for the Iranian state hackers of tomorrow, has itself, ironically, been hacked.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Data Security Posture Management — What Does 'Best in Class' Look Like?
item.description: The emergence of Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) in early 2023, followed by major acquisitions by companies like IBM, Thales, and Palo Alto Networks, demonstrates industry recognition of the need for a more holistic approach to data protection.
item.dc:creator: Adam Strange

item.title: Malicious NPM Packages Disguised With 'Invisible' Dependencies
item.description: In the &quot;PhantomRaven&quot; campaign, threat actors published 126 malicious npm packages that have flown under the radar, while collecting 86,000 downloads.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: AI Search Tools Easily Fooled by Fake Content
item.description: New research shows AI crawlers like Perplexity, Atlas, and ChatGPT are surprisingly easy to fool.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Dentsu Subsidiary Breached, Employee Data Stolen
item.description: A subsidiary of Japanese marketing and PR giant Dentsu lost sensitive data to unidentified threat actors, the parent company said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Microsoft Security Change for Azure VMs Creates Pitfalls
item.description: Firms using Azure infrastructure gained a reprieve from a security-focused switch that could have broken apps that relied on public Internet access.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Botnets Step Up Cloud Attacks Via Flaws, Misconfigurations
item.description: Infamous botnets like Mirai are exploiting Web-exposed assets such as PHP servers, IoT devices, and cloud gateways to gain control over systems and build strength.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Experts Reports Sharp Increase in Automated Botnet Attacks Targeting PHP Servers and IoT Devices
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers are calling attention to a spike in automated attacks targeting PHP servers, IoT devices, and cloud gateways by various botnets such as Mirai, Gafgyt, and Mozi. "These automated campaigns exploit known CVE vulnerabilities and cloud misconfigurations to gain control over exposed systems and expand botnet networks," the Qualys Threat Research Unit (TRU) said in a report
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Coffee with the Council Podcast: Nominate Your Company for the Council’s Next Brazil Regional Engagement Board
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: New AI-Targeted Cloaking Attack Tricks AI Crawlers Into Citing Fake Info as Verified Facts
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have flagged a new security issue in agentic web browsers like OpenAI ChatGPT Atlas that exposes underlying artificial intelligence (AI) models to context poisoning attacks. In the attack devised by AI security company SPLX, a bad actor can set up websites that serve different content to browsers and AI crawlers run by ChatGPT and Perplexity. The technique has been
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: From Power Users to Protective Stewards: How to Tune Security Training for Specialized Employees
item.description: The best security training programs build strong security culture by focusing on high-risk groups, including developers, executives, and finance pros.
item.dc:creator: Ericka Chickowski, Contributing Writer

item.title: Discover Practical AI Tactics for GRC — Join the Free Expert Webinar
item.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly transforming Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC). It's no longer a future concept—it's here, and it's already reshaping how teams operate. AI's capabilities are profound: it's speeding up audits, flagging critical risks faster, and drastically cutting down on time-consuming manual work. This leads to greater efficiency, higher accuracy, and a more
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Preparing for the Digital Battlefield of 2026: Ghost Identities, Poisoned Accounts, & AI Agent Havoc
item.description: BeyondTrust’s annual cybersecurity predictions point to a year where old defenses will fail quietly, and new attack vectors will surge. Introduction The next major breach won’t be a phished password. It will be the result of a massive, unmanaged identity debt. This debt takes many forms: it’s the “ghost” identity from a 2015 breach lurking in your IAM, the privilege sprawl from thousands of new
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Russian Hackers Target Ukrainian Organizations Using Stealthy Living-Off-the-Land Tactics
item.description: Organizations in Ukraine have been targeted by threat actors of Russian origin with an aim to siphon sensitive data and maintain persistent access to compromised networks. The activity, according to a new report from the Symantec and Carbon Black Threat Hunter Team, targeted a large business services organization for two months and a local government entity in the country for a week. The attacks
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Signal’s Post-Quantum Cryptographic Implementation
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Cybersecurity Awareness Month 2025: When seeing isn't believing
item.description: Deepfakes are blurring the line between real and fake and fraudsters are cashing in, using synthetic media for all manner of scams
